awd_titl_txt: Integrated Data-driven Technologies for Individualized Instruction in STEM Learning Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to develop intelligent learning technology designed to react to individual student performance data, so as to personalize instruction. Such technology has significant potential to transform the American educational system by providing a low-cost way to adapt learning environments to individual students' needs and by informing advanced research on human learning. This project will create the technology for a new generation of data-driven Intelligent Tutoring Systems (ITSs), enabling the rapid creation of individualized instruction that supports learning in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). The net result of this work will be a modular framework of educational data mining methods that offer student-adaptive, individualized support at multiple granularities, that have been implemented, iteratively refined, and empirically validated for learning impact and robustness across systems. This project will develop hierarchical data-driven, interpretable, and robust models that optimize student learning. Moreover, it will investigate whether integrating hierarchical data-driven agent decision-making with user-initiated decisions can help students learn to make better decisions for their learning. Teaching students to make effective decisions can fundamentally transform educational assessment: the emphasis should not be just on what students have learned, but on whether students can learn and adapt in productive ways in future situations. By providing individualized instruction using data, it has the potential to make individualized learning support accessible to a broad audience, including students that are traditionally underrepresented in STEM fields. These efforts serve the national interests by strengthening the nation's ability to develop and diversify the STEM workforce.

The goal of this project is to develop and empirically evaluate a general hierarchical data-driven framework that would induce hierarchical hints and adaptive hierarchical pedagogical decision making policies across three STEM domains, including logic, probability, and programming, where building traditional ITSs is extremely challenging. More specifically, this project will 1) advance research on data-driven approaches to ITSs by adapting them to make subgoal hints and hierarchical decisions similar to those of human experts; 2) evaluate the robustness of our general hierarchical data-driven framework by comparing it to flat data-driven approaches not only on each individual ITS but also across ITSs; and 3) close the loop by using data-driven policies to improve students' decision-making and their long-term problem-solving abilities. The proposed work is poised to have a significant impact by making ITSs more effective, by improving student performance in STEM domains, and by teaching students to make effective pedagogical decisions. If successful, it will close the loop by using data-driven policies to support student decision-making and eventually improve their long-term problem-solving abilities through hybrid human-machine interactive decision-making in-vivo experimentation.

por.por_cntn:
This IUSE DIP: Integrated Data-driven Technologies for Individualized Instruction in STEM Learning Environments project has developed intelligent learning technology designed to react to individual student performance data, so as to personalize instruction.  We have developed a general learning platform that unites our existing data-driven Intelligent Tutoring Systems (ITSs), Deep Thought logic tutor, and Pyrenees probability tutor, with intelligent student support derived from data that will decide both what to teach, and how to teach it. More specifically, our data-driven platform can now generate proactive partially worked steps called proactive hints, the what for intelligent support, and our data-driven platform can now induce hierarchical pedagogical decisions on what action to take when there are multiple options available, the how for intelligent support. In this project, we focused on the two types of pedagogical decisions. The first type is about when we should provide proactive hints to students.  The second type of pedagogical decision is about determining what content to present next.  ITSs typically operate in two loops. In the outer loop, the tutor makes task or problem-level decisions such as deciding what problem to solve next, while the inner loop controls step-level decisions such as whether or not to give a hint.  In this project, we focused on one important type of pedagogical decision at two levels of granularity: at the problem level,  the tutor first decides whether the next problem should be a worked example (WE), problem-solving (PS), or a faded worked example (FWE). In WEs, students observe how the tutor solves a problem; in PSs students solve the problem themselves; in FWEs, the students and the tutor co-construct the solution. Based on the problem-level decision, the HRL policy then makes step-level decisions on whether to elicit the next solution step from the student or to show it to the student directly. We refer to such decisions as elicit/tell decisions. If WEs are selected, an all-tell problem will be presented; if PS is selected, an all-elicit problem will be provided; finally, if FWE is selected, the tutor will decide whether to elicit or to tell the next step.




The net results of this work are a modular framework of educational data mining methods that offer 1) data-driven hint generation; 2) student-adaptive, individualized pedagogical decisions at multiple granularities, and 3) teaching students robust yet transferable pedagogical decisions that they can transfer across different systems. Throughout this project, our framework has been implemented, iteratively refined, and empirically validated for learning impact and robustness across different tutoring systems. This project has developed hierarchical data-driven, interpretable, and robust models that optimize student learning by combining reinforcement learning with a field of logic inspired by human thinking called fuzzy logic; the resulting pedagogical policies may then be read by humans and understood as linguistic control strategies. Moreover, our framework is capable of understanding students’ learning objectives and personalizing explanations regarding the hierarchical data-driven agent’s  actions to individual students, leading to improved learning and engagement. Teaching students to make effective decisions can fundamentally transform educational assessment: the emphasis should not be just on what students have learned, but on whether students can learn and adapt in productive ways in future situations. By providing individualized instruction using data, it has the potential to make individualized learning support accessible to a broad audience, including students that are traditionally underrepresented in STEM fields. These efforts serve the national interests by strengthening the nation's ability to develop and diversify the STEM workforce.

The project has demonstrated the effectiveness of the platform and the general hierarchical framework across three science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) domains, including logic, probability, and programming, in which building traditional Intelligent Tutoring Systems (ITSs) is extremely challenging.  More specifically, this project has the following contributions: 1) it advanced research on data-driven approaches to ITSs by adapting them to make subgoal hints and hierarchical decisions similar to those of human experts; 2) it has run extensive evaluations on the robustness of our general hierarchical data-driven framework by comparing it to flat data-driven approaches not only on each individual ITS but also across ITSs; and 3) close the loop by using data-driven policies to improve students' decision-making and their long-term problem-solving abilities. The project has a significant impact by making ITSs more effective, improving student performance in STEM domains, and teaching students to make effective pedagogical decisions. More importantly, it has shown that our platform closes the loop by using data-driven policies to support student decision-making and eventually improve their long-term problem-solving abilities through hybrid human-machine interactive decision-making in vivo experimentations. We have shown that our developed technology has significant potential to transform the American educational system by providing a low-cost way to adapt learning environments to individual students' needs and by informing advanced research on human learning.
